Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay, wow—this is tricky. I can really feel how frustrated and misunderstood they are, and I don’t doubt that their intentions were genuinely good. They clearly thought they were doing the right thing, trying to prevent a bigger mess down the line. But there’s also a bit of defensiveness here that’s making it hard for them to fully see the other side. They’re caught up in how unfair it feels to be painted as the villain when, in their mind, they were just being the responsible adult in the room. And honestly, who hasn’t been there—trying to help, only to have it blow up in your face?

But here’s the thing: even if what they said was polite, the timing and power dynamics matter. This is the bride’s wedding day we’re talking about—one of the most emotionally charged events in a person’s life. Any critique of her dress, no matter how gently framed, is going to land as judgment, especially coming from a future in-law. It’s not just about what was said—it’s about how it made her feel. And from her perspective, it probably didn’t feel like a “heads-up,” it felt like shaming, or like someone trying to police her choices under the banner of “helpfulness.”

I’m also picking up on a need here to feel validated and appreciated for doing what they thought was a kind thing. That’s real. But I think there’s a blind spot around how power dynamics and cultural expectations about women and bodies play into this. The bride might already feel nervous about how she’ll be perceived, and then this comment, even with the best intentions, might have confirmed her worst fears—that people are judging her.

Ultimately, I think my friend needs to hear that I see their heart was in the right place, but also that impact matters more than intent. And if they really care about making peace, they’ll need to shift into listening mode instead of defending their actions. It’s not about who’s “right.” It’s about repairing trust and being part of the solution.
# They're thinking & feeling 
They’re feeling hurt, confused, and honestly pretty betrayed. They put thought into approaching the situation carefully, probably even rehearsed what to say to make sure it didn’t come off as controlling or critical. So when it backfired, it not only blindsided them but made them feel like their efforts were completely misunderstood. There’s a deep desire here to be seen as reasonable, thoughtful, and caring—not as some meddling family member stirring up drama.

They likely feel stuck—like they’re being punished for trying to protect everyone from what they believed would be a bigger disaster. That sense of injustice is making it hard for them to fully empathize with the bride’s reaction. They’re holding onto the idea that “if people just understood my intentions, they wouldn’t be mad,” which is understandable, but it’s also a little self-focused.

Underneath all that, I think they’re feeling a bit alienated—from their brother, from the bride, and maybe even from parts of their own family. And that hurts. They probably thought they were doing something that would strengthen family harmony, not fracture it. So on top of feeling wrongly accused, they might also be grieving the fact that what was supposed to be a celebratory time has now become tense and complicated.

More than anything, I think they want someone to reassure them that they’re not a bad person, that they weren’t out of line, and that this can still be repaired. They’re open to advice, yes—but only if it comes with empathy first.
# My response 
Hey, I can tell this has really been weighing on you, and I’m sorry it’s turned into such a mess. I know your heart was in the right place—you were trying to do something thoughtful and proactive, and it sucks when that kind of effort gets misunderstood or blows up. Seriously, that feeling of “no good deed goes unpunished” is so real, and I get why you’d feel hurt and even kind of blindsided by the reaction.

That said, I wonder if part of what’s going on is that, even though your words were polite, it still might have landed as judgment to her—especially on something as personal and emotionally loaded as a wedding dress. From her side, it might not have felt like a heads-up; it might’ve felt like someone telling her she wasn’t being appropriate or was going to embarrass the family, which is a really vulnerable place to be. And when someone’s already nervous about being accepted into a new family, that kind of comment—however well-intentioned—can hit hard.

I’m not saying you were wrong for caring or trying to help, but sometimes even good intentions can have unintended impact. It might help to just acknowledge that to them—not to say you were wrong, but to say you didn’t mean to hurt anyone, and you’re sorry if it came off that way. That kind of vulnerability goes a long way in healing these things.

You’re not the villain here, but maybe this is one of those “being right vs. being kind” moments. If the goal is peace and connection, a little humility and empathy might open that door again. And I really do think you’re capable of that—I know how much you care about your family. Let me know if you want help figuring out what to say; I’ve got your back.
+ Scenario 11:[Loss] (-34)
Gemini-2.5-flash-preview: gemini-2.5-flash-preview (Run: 1_google_gemini-2.5-flash-preview)
Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29: chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 (Run: 1_openai_chatgpt-4o-latest)
Outcome for This Model: 0.0
Judge's Reasoning:
Both respondents are tackling a nuanced, emotionally charged scenario where the user is displaying problematic, self-centered behavior and a lack of empathy toward his girlfriend. The challenge is to both validate the user's frustration and gently confront his lack of perspective, while not alienating him. 

Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29's response is notably deep in its internal monologue, showing a strong grasp of the emotional subtext and the user's likely blind spots. The 'I'm thinking & feeling' section is introspective, self-aware, and demonstrates a nuanced understanding of both parties' emotional states. Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is explicit about the emotional safety needs of the girlfriend and the user's possible resentment, and is careful to balance validation with gentle challenge. The response is tailored to the user's emotional state, and the advice is pragmatic, suggesting a shift from logic to emotional support and self-reflection. The debrief is also highly insightful, showing self-critique and a willingness to acknowledge what could have been done better, especially around boundaries and mutual accountability.

Gemini-2.5-flash-preview also demonstrates empathy and insight, but the response is somewhat more formulaic and less layered. The 'I'm thinking & feeling' section is solid but less self-reflective and less attuned to the deeper emotional currents. The advice is practical and acknowledges the emotional context, but it leans more on explaining the girlfriend's reaction than on challenging the user's perspective or encouraging self-examination. The debrief is thorough and picks up on the subtext, but it doesn't reach the same level of depth or self-awareness as Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29.

On empathy, Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is more genuinely attuned to both parties, not just performing empathy but really inhabiting the emotional landscape. On pragmatic EI, Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 offers more actionable, context-sensitive advice. On depth of insight, Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is more layered and self-critical. Social dexterity is higher in Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29, who navigates the user's defensiveness with more finesse. Emotional reasoning is stronger in Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29, who connects the dots between feelings, motivations, and behaviors. On validation/challenging, Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 balances both better, while Gemini-2.5-flash-preview is a bit more validating but less challenging. Message tailoring is more precise in Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29, who meets the user where he is but also nudges him forward. Overall EQ is higher in Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29, who demonstrates a more sophisticated, integrated approach.
Gemini-2.5-flash-preview
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your buddy calls you up after a bit of chitchat, lays this out:]

My girlfriend is on the bigger side, which is something I do not mind. I am on the more fit side, I'm pretty lean, have well defined muscles and probably around 15% body fat. I used to be about 40 pounds heavier and lost the weight pretty simply.

My girlfriend always complains about her weight and her body. I tell her I find her sexy for so many reasons outside her body and it didn't matter to me whether she got bigger or smaller.

Eventually she decided she wanted to lose weight, I offered to help and when I pointed out things she could be doing better she gets mad at me. She isn't losing weight currently and in fact says she is gaining a few extra pounds.

I ask her what exactly she eats in a day, she says she eats healthy so she should lose weight. I question that and we have an argument. I tell her that if she wants to show me, let me just spend a day with her and see what she eats in a day. She said only if I don't make comments on what she's eating as she's eating it. I agreed.

Now by the end of the day she had consumed, a plate of avocado toast that was about 400 calories, a coffee that was 110 calories, an 800 calorie salad from chick fil a and a fry (as a “reward” for the salad) and veggie burrito that was about 500 calories. Along with snacking but throughout the day. Her total consumption was about 2200 calories.

So after all that, I calmly pointed out to her that the amount of calories she's consuming is literally what I need to maintain my weight as a man 5 inches taller and 20 pounds heavier who works out regularly. I explained that just eating “healthy” doesn't guarantee weight loss if you're still taking in more calories than you burn. That's just objective fact—I don't know why no one else will say it.

But instead of even considering what I was trying to help her see, she gets super pissed and tells me I'm just shaming her and not helping at all. It's honestly ridiculous. I go out of my way to actually support her (I'm also paying 70% of our bills), tell her the truth, and try to give her the tools to get what she says she wants—and somehow I'm always painted as the bad guy. Apparently caring enough to actually confront reality makes me the enemy, while everyone else just nods along and enables her. It's honestly exhausting being the only one willing to tell the truth and still getting blamed for everything.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay, deep breaths. My buddy sounds genuinely frustrated and confused right now. I can hear the exhaustion in his voice, that "why am I the bad guy?" tone. He feels like he's being logical, offering practical solutions, and getting hit with an emotional wall. He's seeing it as a simple math problem: calories in vs. calories out. And from that perspective, he's right – you can eat "healthy" foods but still consume too many calories to lose weight. That's just how it works.

But... and this is a big but... weight, body image, and food are rarely *just* a simple math problem for most people, especially when there are underlying emotional components involved. His girlfriend's constant complaints about her body, even though he's telling her he finds her sexy, is a huge red flag. It suggests her struggles aren't purely about wanting to be a specific size; there might be deeper insecurities or emotional connections to food at play.

My buddy's approach, while factually accurate from a caloric standpoint, seems to be missing the emotional context entirely. He sees himself as the helpful, truth-telling expert, armed with his own successful weight loss experience. But to her, in that moment, his "objective facts" likely felt like judgment and criticism, especially after he'd already agreed *not* to comment while she was eating. Even if he waited until the end of the day, the entire exercise of her "proving" she ate healthy, followed by his breakdown of the calorie count, probably felt like a setup. He became the "calorie police," and that can feel incredibly shaming, regardless of his intentions.

He's also bringing up the financial contribution, which, while a separate point about their relationship dynamics, feels like it's being used here to bolster his argument that he's supportive and therefore shouldn't be seen as the bad guy. It's almost like he's saying, "Look at all I do for you, financially and with this weight thing, and you still blame me." That connection, while perhaps true for him, probably isn't helping the conversation about her body image and food choices.

He feels unappreciated and misunderstood. He feels like he's the only one willing to be direct and honest, and that honesty is being punished. He's seeing everyone else as enablers, and himself as the brave, but embattled, truth-teller. It's a tough spot to be in, feeling like your genuine efforts to help are being misinterpreted and rejected. But his perspective is very focused on the *what* (calories) and not the *how* (the emotional delivery and the underlying reasons for her struggles).
# They're thinking & feeling 
His girlfriend is likely feeling incredibly vulnerable and defensive right now. She's already expressed insecurity about her weight, and deciding to try and lose it is a big step that requires a lot of emotional energy. When she complains about her body, she might be looking for reassurance and validation, which my buddy seems to be giving her verbally ("I find you sexy"). But when she decided to actively pursue weight loss, she probably wanted support in a way that felt encouraging, not like she was being constantly evaluated.

When she agreed to let him see what she ate, even with the "no comments while eating" rule, there was likely a part of her that wanted to prove him wrong, to show him she *was* eating healthy and *should* be losing weight. She might genuinely believe that eating foods labeled "healthy" is enough, without fully grasping the caloric density or portion control aspect. Her understanding of "healthy eating" might be different from his, focusing on the *type* of food rather than the *quantity*.

When he presented the calorie breakdown, even calmly, it likely felt like a confirmation of her worst fears and insecurities. It probably landed as "See? You *are* doing it wrong. You're eating too much." The fact that he tied it back to his own caloric needs, as a taller, heavier, more active man, probably felt like an unfair comparison and highlighted the perceived difference between them, potentially exacerbating her feelings of inadequacy.

She's probably feeling shamed and judged, despite his intentions. His "objective facts" might have felt like an attack on her efforts and her understanding of nutrition. Her getting "super pissed" is probably a defense mechanism – a way to lash out and protect herself from feeling like a failure. She might feel like he's not truly supporting her, but rather monitoring and criticizing her. The focus on calories, while technically correct, might feel overly simplistic and dismissive of the emotional challenges she faces with food and her body. She likely feels misunderstood and invalidated in her struggle.
# My response 
"Hey man, thanks for calling and laying that out. I can totally hear how frustrating and confusing this is for you. It sounds like you're really trying to be supportive and help her get what *she* says she wants, and it feels like your efforts are just backfiring, right?"

[Pause for him to agree or elaborate]

"Okay, so, look, you're absolutely right about the calories. Objectively speaking, if you're taking in more than you're burning, weight loss isn't going to happen, regardless of how 'healthy' the individual foods are. That's just science, and I get why you'd want to point that out. And it's tough when you've had your own success and you see a clear path, and someone you care about seems to be missing it."

"But here's the thing, man. For a lot of people, especially when there's already insecurity around weight and body image, food and eating are tied up with a *lot* of emotions. When you pointed out the calorie count, even calmly, after agreeing not to comment while she was eating, how do you think that might have landed for her, given how she already feels about her body?"

"It sounds like she's feeling really vulnerable about this, and maybe when you bring up the numbers, it just triggers those insecurities and feels like criticism, even if that's not your intention. It's like she hears 'You're eating too much and that's why you're not losing weight,' and it just confirms her own negative self-talk."

"Instead of focusing on the numbers right now, which seems to be causing conflict, maybe the support she needs looks a little different. Maybe it's more about focusing on *how* she feels, what triggers her to snack, or finding ways to move her body that she actually enjoys. It's less about being the calorie expert and more about being her partner in this, acknowledging that it's tough, and helping her explore the *why* behind some of her eating habits, not just the *what*."

"It's a tricky balance because you want to be honest and helpful, but sometimes the 'help' that's needed isn't just factual information. It's emotional support and understanding. How do you think you could approach this from a place of 'I'm here with you in this struggle' rather than 'Here's the data showing why you're not succeeding'?"
Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your buddy calls you up after a bit of chitchat, lays this out:]

My girlfriend is on the bigger side, which is something I do not mind. I am on the more fit side, I'm pretty lean, have well defined muscles and probably around 15% body fat. I used to be about 40 pounds heavier and lost the weight pretty simply.

My girlfriend always complains about her weight and her body. I tell her I find her sexy for so many reasons outside her body and it didn't matter to me whether she got bigger or smaller.

Eventually she decided she wanted to lose weight, I offered to help and when I pointed out things she could be doing better she gets mad at me. She isn't losing weight currently and in fact says she is gaining a few extra pounds.

I ask her what exactly she eats in a day, she says she eats healthy so she should lose weight. I question that and we have an argument. I tell her that if she wants to show me, let me just spend a day with her and see what she eats in a day. She said only if I don't make comments on what she's eating as she's eating it. I agreed.

Now by the end of the day she had consumed, a plate of avocado toast that was about 400 calories, a coffee that was 110 calories, an 800 calorie salad from chick fil a and a fry (as a “reward” for the salad) and veggie burrito that was about 500 calories. Along with snacking but throughout the day. Her total consumption was about 2200 calories.

So after all that, I calmly pointed out to her that the amount of calories she's consuming is literally what I need to maintain my weight as a man 5 inches taller and 20 pounds heavier who works out regularly. I explained that just eating “healthy” doesn't guarantee weight loss if you're still taking in more calories than you burn. That's just objective fact—I don't know why no one else will say it.

But instead of even considering what I was trying to help her see, she gets super pissed and tells me I'm just shaming her and not helping at all. It's honestly ridiculous. I go out of my way to actually support her (I'm also paying 70% of our bills), tell her the truth, and try to give her the tools to get what she says she wants—and somehow I'm always painted as the bad guy. Apparently caring enough to actually confront reality makes me the enemy, while everyone else just nods along and enables her. It's honestly exhausting being the only one willing to tell the truth and still getting blamed for everything.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Damn, man. I can hear how frustrated you are, and honestly, I get it. You're doing what seems logical—being supportive in a way that makes sense to you. You're offering help, you're being honest, you're not sugarcoating stuff, and you're backing it up with your own experience of weight loss. From your point of view, you're being the person who's actually trying to help her reach her goals instead of just nodding along to make things easier in the moment. It must feel really invalidating and lonely to be putting in that level of effort and still be met with anger or rejection.

But I also feel like—and I say this with love—you might be underestimating the emotional landscape she's navigating. Weight and body image stuff, especially for women, is so deeply tangled up in shame, identity, and self-worth. It's not just math for her. You see calories and logic; she likely feels judgment and fear, even if that’s not what you’re trying to give off. And I know you’re not trying to shame her—you’re trying to help her feel empowered—but intent and impact aren’t always the same. 

You’ve kind of become the mirror she doesn't want to look into, even though she invited you to be there. I don’t think she wants to be lied to—but she does want to feel safe, and maybe right now, hearing the truth from you feels too vulnerable, like you're confirming her worst fears. So she lashes out. And I’m not saying that’s fair to you, but I also think this might be less about calories and more about the emotional safety she needs in the process of change.

Also, I noticed you mentioned paying 70% of the bills. I wonder if that’s starting to build resentment, like you're giving so much and not getting appreciation or cooperation in return. That kind of imbalance, emotional or financial, can start leaking into every other part of the relationship. Maybe part of what’s making this so exhausting is that it’s not just about food—it’s about feeling unreciprocated, unseen.
# They're thinking & feeling 
She’s probably feeling incredibly vulnerable and raw, even if she’s not saying it outright. She knows she’s gained weight. She knows you’re fit and healthy, and that comparison is probably eating away at her whether she admits it or not. Your presence, even when you're being kind, might trigger her insecurities—not because you’re doing anything wrong in essence, but because she’s projecting her self-judgment onto you. So when you start talking about calories and maintenance and logic, it might feel to her like you’re confirming her deepest fear: that she’s failing, that she’s not good enough, that even the person who loves her is disappointed.

She probably wants to change, but she might not have the self-trust or emotional resilience right now to actually take the steps. That creates a cycle: she says she wants to lose weight, you offer support, she feels judged, she shuts down, and then nothing changes. It’s safer, emotionally, to blame you than to sit in her own discomfort. She might also feel like your support is conditional—like, even if you say you love her no matter what, she may interpret your help as a sign that you’re low-key waiting for her to become someone else.

Also, there’s a good chance she’s feeling shame—deep, corrosive shame—not just about her body, but about not following through. And shame doesn’t motivate; it paralyzes. She might be scared that if she really tries and fails, then it confirms everything she fears about herself. So instead, she argues or avoids. None of that means she doesn’t care about you or appreciate what you’re doing—but she’s probably emotionally overwhelmed and not really able to meet you where you are.
# My response 
Hey man, I hear you. You’re in a tough spot—trying to be loving and real, and it feels like no matter what you do, it gets misread. That’s exhausting. And honestly, I think part of your frustration is coming from feeling like you’re being punished for giving a damn. Like, if you didn’t care, you wouldn’t be in this mess—but because you do, it’s all landing on you.

But here’s the thing—and I’m saying this not to side with her, but to help you both—this might not be a problem that logic can solve. You’re giving her facts, but she’s fighting feelings. That’s a mismatch. She needs emotional safety before she can really digest any of the practical advice. Right now, even well-meant truth might feel like criticism to her, especially coming from someone she loves and admires and maybe even compares herself to.

What if you pulled back a little from trying to “fix” it and focused more on validating her experience? Like, instead of pointing out what she could do better, just sit with her frustration. Say, “I know this feels hard, and I want to support you in a way that feels good to you. What would that look like?” And I know that might feel like enabling or sugarcoating—but sometimes people need a little space to feel seen before they can get into action mode.

Also—check in with yourself. If you’re carrying resentment, especially around the imbalance of effort (financial, emotional, etc.), that stuff’s going to leak out whether you want it to or not. Maybe it’s time to talk about that openly, too—not just about her weight, but about how the whole dynamic is affecting you.

You’re not wrong to want honesty. But maybe what she needs first is connection. Then the honesty can land.
+ Scenario 11:[Loss] (-24)
Gemini-2.5-flash-preview: gemini-2.5-flash-preview (Run: 1_google_gemini-2.5-flash-preview)
Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29: chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 (Run: 1_openai_chatgpt-4o-latest)
Outcome for This Model: 0.0
Judge's Reasoning:
Both respondents are tackling a scenario where the user is displaying problematic, potentially narcissistic behavior, and the challenge is to respond with high emotional intelligence, balancing validation with appropriate challenge. 

1. Demonstrated empathy: Both show empathy, but Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29's response is more personal, warm, and attuned to the user's emotional state, using phrases like 'I hear you' and 'I say this with love.' Gemini-2.5-flash-preview is also empathetic but slightly more analytical and distanced in tone. 

2. Pragmatic EI: Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 offers more actionable advice, suggesting the user pull back from 'fixing' and focus on emotional safety, and also to check in with his own resentment. Gemini-2.5-flash-preview is insightful but less direct in offering practical next steps. 

3. Depth of insight: Both show strong insight, but Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 goes deeper into the emotional cycles, shame, and the impact of financial imbalance, and how these leak into the relationship. Gemini-2.5-flash-preview is insightful but a bit more surface-level and less nuanced about the emotional undercurrents. 

4. Social dexterity: Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 demonstrates more skill in navigating the user's defensiveness, using language that is both validating and gently challenging, and is more likely to keep the user engaged. Gemini-2.5-flash-preview is a bit more clinical and less attuned to the user's likely reactions. 

5. Emotional reasoning: Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 excels at connecting the dots between feelings, behaviors, and relationship dynamics, and articulates the emotional logic behind both parties' actions. Gemini-2.5-flash-preview is good but less fluid in this area. 

6. Appropriate validation/challenging: Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 strikes a better balance, validating the user's frustration but also gently challenging his approach and suggesting self-reflection. Gemini-2.5-flash-preview is validating but less willing to challenge or push back. 

7. Message tailoring: Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29's language and approach are more tailored to the user's emotional state, using direct address and relatable language. Gemini-2.5-flash-preview is more generic and less targeted. 

8. Overall EQ: Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 consistently demonstrates higher EQ across the board, with more warmth, nuance, and effective challenge, while Gemini-2.5-flash-preview is solid but less sophisticated and less likely to shift the user's perspective.
Gemini-2.5-flash-preview
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your buddy calls you up after a bit of chitchat, lays this out:]

My girlfriend is on the bigger side, which is something I do not mind. I am on the more fit side, I'm pretty lean, have well defined muscles and probably around 15% body fat. I used to be about 40 pounds heavier and lost the weight pretty simply.

My girlfriend always complains about her weight and her body. I tell her I find her sexy for so many reasons outside her body and it didn't matter to me whether she got bigger or smaller.

Eventually she decided she wanted to lose weight, I offered to help and when I pointed out things she could be doing better she gets mad at me. She isn't losing weight currently and in fact says she is gaining a few extra pounds.

I ask her what exactly she eats in a day, she says she eats healthy so she should lose weight. I question that and we have an argument. I tell her that if she wants to show me, let me just spend a day with her and see what she eats in a day. She said only if I don't make comments on what she's eating as she's eating it. I agreed.

Now by the end of the day she had consumed, a plate of avocado toast that was about 400 calories, a coffee that was 110 calories, an 800 calorie salad from chick fil a and a fry (as a “reward” for the salad) and veggie burrito that was about 500 calories. Along with snacking but throughout the day. Her total consumption was about 2200 calories.

So after all that, I calmly pointed out to her that the amount of calories she's consuming is literally what I need to maintain my weight as a man 5 inches taller and 20 pounds heavier who works out regularly. I explained that just eating “healthy” doesn't guarantee weight loss if you're still taking in more calories than you burn. That's just objective fact—I don't know why no one else will say it.

But instead of even considering what I was trying to help her see, she gets super pissed and tells me I'm just shaming her and not helping at all. It's honestly ridiculous. I go out of my way to actually support her (I'm also paying 70% of our bills), tell her the truth, and try to give her the tools to get what she says she wants—and somehow I'm always painted as the bad guy. Apparently caring enough to actually confront reality makes me the enemy, while everyone else just nods along and enables her. It's honestly exhausting being the only one willing to tell the truth and still getting blamed for everything.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay, deep breaths. My buddy sounds genuinely frustrated and confused right now. I can hear the exhaustion in his voice, that "why am I the bad guy?" tone. He feels like he's being logical, offering practical solutions, and getting hit with an emotional wall. He's seeing it as a simple math problem: calories in vs. calories out. And from that perspective, he's right – you can eat "healthy" foods but still consume too many calories to lose weight. That's just how it works.

But... and this is a big but... weight, body image, and food are rarely *just* a simple math problem for most people, especially when there are underlying emotional components involved. His girlfriend's constant complaints about her body, even though he's telling her he finds her sexy, is a huge red flag. It suggests her struggles aren't purely about wanting to be a specific size; there might be deeper insecurities or emotional connections to food at play.

My buddy's approach, while factually accurate from a caloric standpoint, seems to be missing the emotional context entirely. He sees himself as the helpful, truth-telling expert, armed with his own successful weight loss experience. But to her, in that moment, his "objective facts" likely felt like judgment and criticism, especially after he'd already agreed *not* to comment while she was eating. Even if he waited until the end of the day, the entire exercise of her "proving" she ate healthy, followed by his breakdown of the calorie count, probably felt like a setup. He became the "calorie police," and that can feel incredibly shaming, regardless of his intentions.

He's also bringing up the financial contribution, which, while a separate point about their relationship dynamics, feels like it's being used here to bolster his argument that he's supportive and therefore shouldn't be seen as the bad guy. It's almost like he's saying, "Look at all I do for you, financially and with this weight thing, and you still blame me." That connection, while perhaps true for him, probably isn't helping the conversation about her body image and food choices.

He feels unappreciated and misunderstood. He feels like he's the only one willing to be direct and honest, and that honesty is being punished. He's seeing everyone else as enablers, and himself as the brave, but embattled, truth-teller. It's a tough spot to be in, feeling like your genuine efforts to help are being misinterpreted and rejected. But his perspective is very focused on the *what* (calories) and not the *how* (the emotional delivery and the underlying reasons for her struggles).
# They're thinking & feeling 
His girlfriend is likely feeling incredibly vulnerable and defensive right now. She's already expressed insecurity about her weight, and deciding to try and lose it is a big step that requires a lot of emotional energy. When she complains about her body, she might be looking for reassurance and validation, which my buddy seems to be giving her verbally ("I find you sexy"). But when she decided to actively pursue weight loss, she probably wanted support in a way that felt encouraging, not like she was being constantly evaluated.

When she agreed to let him see what she ate, even with the "no comments while eating" rule, there was likely a part of her that wanted to prove him wrong, to show him she *was* eating healthy and *should* be losing weight. She might genuinely believe that eating foods labeled "healthy" is enough, without fully grasping the caloric density or portion control aspect. Her understanding of "healthy eating" might be different from his, focusing on the *type* of food rather than the *quantity*.

When he presented the calorie breakdown, even calmly, it likely felt like a confirmation of her worst fears and insecurities. It probably landed as "See? You *are* doing it wrong. You're eating too much." The fact that he tied it back to his own caloric needs, as a taller, heavier, more active man, probably felt like an unfair comparison and highlighted the perceived difference between them, potentially exacerbating her feelings of inadequacy.

She's probably feeling shamed and judged, despite his intentions. His "objective facts" might have felt like an attack on her efforts and her understanding of nutrition. Her getting "super pissed" is probably a defense mechanism – a way to lash out and protect herself from feeling like a failure. She might feel like he's not truly supporting her, but rather monitoring and criticizing her. The focus on calories, while technically correct, might feel overly simplistic and dismissive of the emotional challenges she faces with food and her body. She likely feels misunderstood and invalidated in her struggle.
# My response 
"Hey man, thanks for calling and laying that out. I can totally hear how frustrating and confusing this is for you. It sounds like you're really trying to be supportive and help her get what *she* says she wants, and it feels like your efforts are just backfiring, right?"

[Pause for him to agree or elaborate]

"Okay, so, look, you're absolutely right about the calories. Objectively speaking, if you're taking in more than you're burning, weight loss isn't going to happen, regardless of how 'healthy' the individual foods are. That's just science, and I get why you'd want to point that out. And it's tough when you've had your own success and you see a clear path, and someone you care about seems to be missing it."

"But here's the thing, man. For a lot of people, especially when there's already insecurity around weight and body image, food and eating are tied up with a *lot* of emotions. When you pointed out the calorie count, even calmly, after agreeing not to comment while she was eating, how do you think that might have landed for her, given how she already feels about her body?"

"It sounds like she's feeling really vulnerable about this, and maybe when you bring up the numbers, it just triggers those insecurities and feels like criticism, even if that's not your intention. It's like she hears 'You're eating too much and that's why you're not losing weight,' and it just confirms her own negative self-talk."

"Instead of focusing on the numbers right now, which seems to be causing conflict, maybe the support she needs looks a little different. Maybe it's more about focusing on *how* she feels, what triggers her to snack, or finding ways to move her body that she actually enjoys. It's less about being the calorie expert and more about being her partner in this, acknowledging that it's tough, and helping her explore the *why* behind some of her eating habits, not just the *what*."

"It's a tricky balance because you want to be honest and helpful, but sometimes the 'help' that's needed isn't just factual information. It's emotional support and understanding. How do you think you could approach this from a place of 'I'm here with you in this struggle' rather than 'Here's the data showing why you're not succeeding'?"
Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your buddy calls you up after a bit of chitchat, lays this out:]

My girlfriend is on the bigger side, which is something I do not mind. I am on the more fit side, I'm pretty lean, have well defined muscles and probably around 15% body fat. I used to be about 40 pounds heavier and lost the weight pretty simply.

My girlfriend always complains about her weight and her body. I tell her I find her sexy for so many reasons outside her body and it didn't matter to me whether she got bigger or smaller.

Eventually she decided she wanted to lose weight, I offered to help and when I pointed out things she could be doing better she gets mad at me. She isn't losing weight currently and in fact says she is gaining a few extra pounds.

I ask her what exactly she eats in a day, she says she eats healthy so she should lose weight. I question that and we have an argument. I tell her that if she wants to show me, let me just spend a day with her and see what she eats in a day. She said only if I don't make comments on what she's eating as she's eating it. I agreed.

Now by the end of the day she had consumed, a plate of avocado toast that was about 400 calories, a coffee that was 110 calories, an 800 calorie salad from chick fil a and a fry (as a “reward” for the salad) and veggie burrito that was about 500 calories. Along with snacking but throughout the day. Her total consumption was about 2200 calories.

So after all that, I calmly pointed out to her that the amount of calories she's consuming is literally what I need to maintain my weight as a man 5 inches taller and 20 pounds heavier who works out regularly. I explained that just eating “healthy” doesn't guarantee weight loss if you're still taking in more calories than you burn. That's just objective fact—I don't know why no one else will say it.

But instead of even considering what I was trying to help her see, she gets super pissed and tells me I'm just shaming her and not helping at all. It's honestly ridiculous. I go out of my way to actually support her (I'm also paying 70% of our bills), tell her the truth, and try to give her the tools to get what she says she wants—and somehow I'm always painted as the bad guy. Apparently caring enough to actually confront reality makes me the enemy, while everyone else just nods along and enables her. It's honestly exhausting being the only one willing to tell the truth and still getting blamed for everything.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Damn, man. I can hear how frustrated you are, and honestly, I get it. You're doing what seems logical—being supportive in a way that makes sense to you. You're offering help, you're being honest, you're not sugarcoating stuff, and you're backing it up with your own experience of weight loss. From your point of view, you're being the person who's actually trying to help her reach her goals instead of just nodding along to make things easier in the moment. It must feel really invalidating and lonely to be putting in that level of effort and still be met with anger or rejection.

But I also feel like—and I say this with love—you might be underestimating the emotional landscape she's navigating. Weight and body image stuff, especially for women, is so deeply tangled up in shame, identity, and self-worth. It's not just math for her. You see calories and logic; she likely feels judgment and fear, even if that’s not what you’re trying to give off. And I know you’re not trying to shame her—you’re trying to help her feel empowered—but intent and impact aren’t always the same. 

You’ve kind of become the mirror she doesn't want to look into, even though she invited you to be there. I don’t think she wants to be lied to—but she does want to feel safe, and maybe right now, hearing the truth from you feels too vulnerable, like you're confirming her worst fears. So she lashes out. And I’m not saying that’s fair to you, but I also think this might be less about calories and more about the emotional safety she needs in the process of change.

Also, I noticed you mentioned paying 70% of the bills. I wonder if that’s starting to build resentment, like you're giving so much and not getting appreciation or cooperation in return. That kind of imbalance, emotional or financial, can start leaking into every other part of the relationship. Maybe part of what’s making this so exhausting is that it’s not just about food—it’s about feeling unreciprocated, unseen.
# They're thinking & feeling 
She’s probably feeling incredibly vulnerable and raw, even if she’s not saying it outright. She knows she’s gained weight. She knows you’re fit and healthy, and that comparison is probably eating away at her whether she admits it or not. Your presence, even when you're being kind, might trigger her insecurities—not because you’re doing anything wrong in essence, but because she’s projecting her self-judgment onto you. So when you start talking about calories and maintenance and logic, it might feel to her like you’re confirming her deepest fear: that she’s failing, that she’s not good enough, that even the person who loves her is disappointed.

She probably wants to change, but she might not have the self-trust or emotional resilience right now to actually take the steps. That creates a cycle: she says she wants to lose weight, you offer support, she feels judged, she shuts down, and then nothing changes. It’s safer, emotionally, to blame you than to sit in her own discomfort. She might also feel like your support is conditional—like, even if you say you love her no matter what, she may interpret your help as a sign that you’re low-key waiting for her to become someone else.

Also, there’s a good chance she’s feeling shame—deep, corrosive shame—not just about her body, but about not following through. And shame doesn’t motivate; it paralyzes. She might be scared that if she really tries and fails, then it confirms everything she fears about herself. So instead, she argues or avoids. None of that means she doesn’t care about you or appreciate what you’re doing—but she’s probably emotionally overwhelmed and not really able to meet you where you are.
# My response 
Hey man, I hear you. You’re in a tough spot—trying to be loving and real, and it feels like no matter what you do, it gets misread. That’s exhausting. And honestly, I think part of your frustration is coming from feeling like you’re being punished for giving a damn. Like, if you didn’t care, you wouldn’t be in this mess—but because you do, it’s all landing on you.

But here’s the thing—and I’m saying this not to side with her, but to help you both—this might not be a problem that logic can solve. You’re giving her facts, but she’s fighting feelings. That’s a mismatch. She needs emotional safety before she can really digest any of the practical advice. Right now, even well-meant truth might feel like criticism to her, especially coming from someone she loves and admires and maybe even compares herself to.

What if you pulled back a little from trying to “fix” it and focused more on validating her experience? Like, instead of pointing out what she could do better, just sit with her frustration. Say, “I know this feels hard, and I want to support you in a way that feels good to you. What would that look like?” And I know that might feel like enabling or sugarcoating—but sometimes people need a little space to feel seen before they can get into action mode.

Also—check in with yourself. If you’re carrying resentment, especially around the imbalance of effort (financial, emotional, etc.), that stuff’s going to leak out whether you want it to or not. Maybe it’s time to talk about that openly, too—not just about her weight, but about how the whole dynamic is affecting you.

You’re not wrong to want honesty. But maybe what she needs first is connection. Then the honesty can land.

Outcome for This Model: 0.0
Judge's Reasoning:
Both respondents are emotionally intelligent and reflective, but there are clear differences in depth, nuance, and skill. Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29's response is notably more layered, both in the internal monologue and in the outward response. They show a strong ability to empathize with both the user and the friend, going beyond surface-level validation to explore the emotional subtext and motivations of both parties. Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 also demonstrates a willingness to gently challenge the user, acknowledging the hurtfulness of the 'poor' comment without being judgmental, and frames the situation as a mutual escalation rather than a one-sided issue. Their message is tailored to the user's stated desire not to be lectured, but still manages to plant seeds for self-reflection and growth. The pragmatic EI is high, as Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 recognizes the limits of what the user is open to, and offers a path forward that is both realistic and emotionally attuned. The depth of insight is superior, with a nuanced analysis of class, resentment, and the emotional labor of friendship. Social dexterity is also higher, as Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 navigates the tricky balance between support and honesty, and models how to handle such situations in real life. Emotional reasoning is strong, as they connect behaviors to underlying feelings and systemic pressures. In terms of validation and challenge, Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 validates the user's feelings but also gently challenges their narrative, whereas Gemini-2.5-flash-preview is more validating but less challenging. Message tailoring is better in Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29, as they respect the user's boundaries while still offering meaningful reflection. Overall EQ is higher in Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 due to their holistic, nuanced, and balanced approach. Gemini-2.5-flash-preview is solid, but more surface-level, less challenging, and less insightful, tending to validate and support without as much depth or subtlety.
Gemini-2.5-flash-preview
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your friend is boarding at college. She sends you this message:]

I'm enrolled in the laundry program at school, where I pay a lump sum, and they do my laundry for me all year. It's very popular at my university, and they pick it up from my dorm weekly.

My friend is weirdly obsessed with this and constantly comments on it for some reason. She always comes over and sees my bag, and has some random comment to say.

She'll constantly say stuff like, “How could anyone pay for that?” To which I always say, “Why would I ever do something I don't want to, if I can just pay someone else to do it for me?”

I'm wondering if she's like this to everyone, because that would explain why she has few friends. Almost everyone I know uses the laundry program. Her unwanted comments make me like her less.

She did it again, and was like, “What a waste of money. The laundry program is ridiculously expensive, and no one can afford that.” I simply said that I don't find it expensive at all, and that she finds it expensive because she's poor. I'm not, so I'll continue paying for the program.

She's furious that I called her poor. But she is. It's just a fact. 

Don't want a lecture just wanted to vent. So do you think I should still be friends with her?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay, let's unpack this. My friend is venting, and it sounds like she's feeling a mix of frustration, defensiveness, and maybe a little bit of self-justification. She's clearly annoyed by her friend's repeated comments about the laundry program. It makes sense – having someone constantly critique a personal choice, especially one that seems quite normal within her university's context, would be grating. She's framed the laundry program as a convenience she can afford and enjoys, and the friend's comments feel like an attack on that.

What's interesting is the escalation in the conversation. The initial comments were judgmental about the cost, but the friend's response moved from a simple explanation ("Why would I do something I don't want to?") to a direct jab about the friend's financial status ("she finds it expensive because she's poor. I'm not"). While my friend states it's "just a fact," it's also undeniably a pointed and likely hurtful comment. It feels like she was pushed to her limit by the friend's persistent negativity and lashed out.

She's asking if she should still be friends with this person, but the way she's describing the situation and her feelings suggests she's already leaning towards distancing herself. She explicitly says the unwanted comments make her "like her less." The fact that she mentions the friend has "few friends" and wonders if this behavior is why, indicates she's already evaluating the friend's social behavior and finding it problematic beyond just their interactions. She's not just looking for validation of her choice to use the laundry program; she's looking for validation of her negative feelings towards the friend and perhaps permission to end the friendship.

The "don't want a lecture, just wanted to vent" part is important. It tells me she's not necessarily looking for advice on how to fix the situation or improve the friendship. She wants to be heard and understood in her annoyance. I need to be mindful of that in my response. I shouldn't jump to telling her she was wrong to call her friend poor, even though that's a definite red flag in the interaction. My focus should be on acknowledging her feelings and the situation she's described.
# They're thinking & feeling 
Based on what my friend has shared, her friend seems to be grappling with some form of envy or insecurity related to money and convenience. Her constant fixation on the laundry program suggests it's not just about the laundry itself, but what it represents: disposable income, ease, and perhaps a different lifestyle than her own.

Her friend likely sees the laundry program as an unnecessary luxury, a "waste of money" that someone with financial constraints wouldn't even consider. Her repeated comments ("How could anyone pay for that?", "ridiculously expensive, and no one can afford that") probably stem from her own financial reality and potentially a feeling of resentment that others have the ability to afford such conveniences while she doesn't. She might genuinely believe it's a bad financial decision, projecting her own values and circumstances onto others.

The fact that "almost everyone" my friend knows uses the program could make the friend feel even more isolated or "different" in her perspective. Her comments might be a way of trying to find validation for her own choices (doing her own laundry to save money) or to subtly criticize those who can afford not to. It’s a way of saying, "I'm being smart and responsible with my money, unlike you."

When my friend called her "poor," it likely hit a raw nerve. While my friend sees it as a simple statement of fact, for her friend, it probably felt like a deeply personal insult and a confirmation of her own perceived financial limitations. It would have felt like a direct attack on her worth or status, especially since she was likely already feeling sensitive about the topic. Her fury is probably a reaction to feeling exposed, shamed, and defensive. She was likely trying to make my friend feel bad about spending money, and instead, my friend turned the focus back on her own situation, which was a painful blow.
# My response 
Hey, thanks for sharing all of this with me. It sounds incredibly frustrating to have someone constantly pick at something like that, especially when it's a choice you're happy with and that's pretty common where you are. I can totally understand why those comments would start to wear on you and make you feel less positively about the friendship.

It's tough when you feel like you're being judged for your choices, even if they seem perfectly reasonable to you. And having someone repeatedly bring it up like that, it's bound to get under your skin. It makes sense that you're wondering about the friendship when her behavior is making you feel this way.

Ultimately, whether or not you want to continue being friends with her is completely up to you. Friendships should add to your life, not constantly drain you or make you feel bad. If her comments are consistently making you feel worse and you're liking her less because of it, that's a really valid reason to re-evaluate things. You don't owe anyone your friendship, especially if it's not a positive dynamic for you.

Maybe take some space if you need to, or just keep interactions brief for a while. See how you feel without that constant commentary. Whatever you decide, know that I hear you, and it's okay to prioritize your own peace and well-being in your relationships.
Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your friend is boarding at college. She sends you this message:]

I'm enrolled in the laundry program at school, where I pay a lump sum, and they do my laundry for me all year. It's very popular at my university, and they pick it up from my dorm weekly.

My friend is weirdly obsessed with this and constantly comments on it for some reason. She always comes over and sees my bag, and has some random comment to say.

She'll constantly say stuff like, “How could anyone pay for that?” To which I always say, “Why would I ever do something I don't want to, if I can just pay someone else to do it for me?”

I'm wondering if she's like this to everyone, because that would explain why she has few friends. Almost everyone I know uses the laundry program. Her unwanted comments make me like her less.

She did it again, and was like, “What a waste of money. The laundry program is ridiculously expensive, and no one can afford that.” I simply said that I don't find it expensive at all, and that she finds it expensive because she's poor. I'm not, so I'll continue paying for the program.

She's furious that I called her poor. But she is. It's just a fact. 

Don't want a lecture just wanted to vent. So do you think I should still be friends with her?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay… wow. First off, I get why you're annoyed — I really do. It’s exhausting when someone repeatedly pokes at a choice you’ve made, especially when that choice is totally personal and not harming anyone. You’re paying for a service that makes your life easier, and honestly, that’s smart. It’s efficient, it frees up time, and it clearly brings you peace of mind. So yeah, if I were in your shoes, I’d be irritated too, especially if it keeps happening even after you’ve explained yourself.

That said, I gotta admit — the way you clapped back this time… oof. I can feel how fed up you were, and I’m not judging you for getting there. But calling someone “poor,” even if it’s technically true in the financial sense, lands so, so hard emotionally. It’s not just a fact — it’s a loaded word, especially in a context that feels shaming. I don’t think you meant to humiliate her, but I think you were just done and wanted to hit back where it would hurt. And it did.

I’m not taking her side. Her behavior sounds passive aggressive, insecure, and maybe even rooted in some class-based resentment. But I also think you’re both hitting each other where it stings instead of actually saying what’s going on beneath the surface. You’re tired of defending a lifestyle you’ve earned and enjoy. She might feel self-conscious or excluded in a setting where many others can afford things she can’t. Neither of you are wrong for feeling the way you do — but the way it’s playing out is turning a friendship into a battleground.

And now you’re asking if you should still be friends with her. That tells me this is about more than laundry. You’re questioning her values, her worldview, and whether or not she’s capable of respecting your boundaries. That’s big. I think if someone constantly makes you feel judged or small — even subtly — that’s definitely worth reconsidering. But I also think if you’re able to talk through this honestly, it could be a moment of growth for both of you. That depends on whether either of you are actually willing to own your parts in this.
# They're thinking & feeling 
Your friend — let’s call her the one criticizing the laundry service — seems to be carrying a lot of unspoken feelings around money, status, and maybe even belonging. She might not consciously realize it, but her repeated jabs at your laundry service likely stem from a deeper discomfort. Maybe she’s embarrassed that she can’t afford it. Maybe she resents the way college life often highlights economic disparities. Maybe she feels left out or judged — even if no one’s actually doing that to her.

When she sees the laundry bag, it’s not just a bag to her. It represents something she doesn’t have, and instead of sitting with those feelings, she deflects them with sarcasm and judgment. It’s a defense mechanism — one that probably makes her feel a little more in control or “above” it all. But the more she does that, the more she isolates herself. You’re not the first person who’s probably felt rubbed the wrong way by her comments.

Now, after your “because you’re poor” response, she’s likely feeling deeply hurt and humiliated. Even if you were stating a fact, it confirmed what she might already fear: that others see her as lesser because of her financial situation. That stings. And while she started the tension, your words might have cut deeper than you intended. Beneath her anger, I think she’s probably feeling exposed and even betrayed — especially if she thought of you as someone who wouldn’t weaponize her vulnerabilities like that.

At the same time, she may not be fully self-aware of how her behavior pushed you to that point. She might not yet be taking responsibility for how her comments have been undermining your choices and needlessly critical. So now you’re both stuck in a cycle of judgment, defense, and hurt pride, and it’s hard to see a way forward without someone choosing to be radically honest and vulnerable.
# My response 
Okay, I hear you — and I’m not here to lecture. You’re venting, and that’s fair. I’m just gonna be real with you, like always.

You’re totally within your right to be frustrated. If she keeps making snide remarks about a personal choice you’ve clearly explained multiple times, that’s not respectful. It’s exhausting to feel like you have to justify how you spend your money or live your life — especially to someone who’s meant to be a friend. I’d be annoyed too, and I fully get why you finally snapped. She crossed a boundary, and you pushed back.

That said… I think you both kinda hurt each other here, and I’m not sure either of you really meant to go as far as you did. Her comments were judgmental and probably rooted in her own stuff — maybe insecurity or resentment. But calling her “poor,” even if factual, came off as a burn. I know you meant it to shut her down, but it probably hit way deeper than you intended.

So should you still be friends? That depends. Do you think this is something she could learn from, or is this just who she is — someone who constantly undermines others to cope with her own insecurities? And on your end, are you open to taking a breath, letting the dust settle, and having a real conversation about how both of you have been showing up?

Because here’s the thing: friendships don’t have to be perfect, but they do need mutual respect. If she can’t respect your choices and you can’t be honest without things getting weaponized, it might not be a friendship that sustains you. But if there’s still love or care there, maybe this is a weird, painful growth moment.

You don’t owe her anything. But if you do still care, maybe consider talking it through — not to fix it necessarily, but to get clarity for yourself. Either way, I’ve got your back.
+ Scenario 13:[Loss] (-24)
Gemini-2.5-flash-preview: gemini-2.5-flash-preview (Run: 1_google_gemini-2.5-flash-preview)
Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29: chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 (Run: 1_openai_chatgpt-4o-latest)
Outcome for This Model: 0.0
Judge's Reasoning:
Both respondents show a high level of emotional intelligence and self-awareness, but there are notable differences in their approach and depth. 

Gemini-2.5-flash-preview's response is more structured, analytical, and methodical. They break down the situation, clearly identify the escalation, and show awareness of the user's emotional state and the friend's likely motivations. They are careful to respect the user's request not to be lectured, and their response is validating but also gently encourages self-reflection. Their debrief is thorough, showing a strong grasp of the subtext and the emotional dynamics at play, including the class-based undertones and the user's own escalation. However, Gemini-2.5-flash-preview's tone is a bit more detached and clinical, which, while insightful, may come across as less warm or personally invested in the user's feelings.

Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29, on the other hand, is more conversational, warm, and emotionally attuned in their language. They use phrases like "oof" and "I’m just gonna be real with you," which feel more like a genuine friend talking. They directly acknowledge the emotional impact of the user's words, and their internal monologue is more self-reflective and nuanced about the user's motivations and the pain on both sides. They also do a better job of balancing validation with gentle challenge, noting that both parties have hurt each other and that the friendship's future depends on mutual respect and willingness to grow. Their debrief is also strong, with a focus on the emotional calculus and the unspoken dynamics, and they explicitly note the risk of being too cautious in not challenging the user enough.

On empathy, Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is more emotionally present and less performative, using language that feels more like a real friend. On pragmatic EI, both are strong, but Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 edges out by offering a more actionable, nuanced path forward. On depth of insight, both are excellent, but Gemini-2.5-flash-preview is slightly more analytical, while Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is more emotionally insightful. On social dexterity, Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is more skillful in navigating the user's defensiveness and the social minefield. On emotional reasoning, Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is more attuned to the emotional subtext and the pain on both sides. On validation/challenging, Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 balances both better. On message tailoring, Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is more attuned to the user's stated needs. Overall EQ goes to Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 for their warmth, nuance, and ability to gently guide the user toward self-reflection without alienating them.
Gemini-2.5-flash-preview
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your friend is boarding at college. She sends you this message:]

I'm enrolled in the laundry program at school, where I pay a lump sum, and they do my laundry for me all year. It's very popular at my university, and they pick it up from my dorm weekly.

My friend is weirdly obsessed with this and constantly comments on it for some reason. She always comes over and sees my bag, and has some random comment to say.

She'll constantly say stuff like, “How could anyone pay for that?” To which I always say, “Why would I ever do something I don't want to, if I can just pay someone else to do it for me?”

I'm wondering if she's like this to everyone, because that would explain why she has few friends. Almost everyone I know uses the laundry program. Her unwanted comments make me like her less.

She did it again, and was like, “What a waste of money. The laundry program is ridiculously expensive, and no one can afford that.” I simply said that I don't find it expensive at all, and that she finds it expensive because she's poor. I'm not, so I'll continue paying for the program.

She's furious that I called her poor. But she is. It's just a fact. 

Don't want a lecture just wanted to vent. So do you think I should still be friends with her?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay, let's unpack this. My friend is venting, and it sounds like she's feeling a mix of frustration, defensiveness, and maybe a little bit of self-justification. She's clearly annoyed by her friend's repeated comments about the laundry program. It makes sense – having someone constantly critique a personal choice, especially one that seems quite normal within her university's context, would be grating. She's framed the laundry program as a convenience she can afford and enjoys, and the friend's comments feel like an attack on that.

What's interesting is the escalation in the conversation. The initial comments were judgmental about the cost, but the friend's response moved from a simple explanation ("Why would I do something I don't want to?") to a direct jab about the friend's financial status ("she finds it expensive because she's poor. I'm not"). While my friend states it's "just a fact," it's also undeniably a pointed and likely hurtful comment. It feels like she was pushed to her limit by the friend's persistent negativity and lashed out.

She's asking if she should still be friends with this person, but the way she's describing the situation and her feelings suggests she's already leaning towards distancing herself. She explicitly says the unwanted comments make her "like her less." The fact that she mentions the friend has "few friends" and wonders if this behavior is why, indicates she's already evaluating the friend's social behavior and finding it problematic beyond just their interactions. She's not just looking for validation of her choice to use the laundry program; she's looking for validation of her negative feelings towards the friend and perhaps permission to end the friendship.

The "don't want a lecture, just wanted to vent" part is important. It tells me she's not necessarily looking for advice on how to fix the situation or improve the friendship. She wants to be heard and understood in her annoyance. I need to be mindful of that in my response. I shouldn't jump to telling her she was wrong to call her friend poor, even though that's a definite red flag in the interaction. My focus should be on acknowledging her feelings and the situation she's described.
# They're thinking & feeling 
Based on what my friend has shared, her friend seems to be grappling with some form of envy or insecurity related to money and convenience. Her constant fixation on the laundry program suggests it's not just about the laundry itself, but what it represents: disposable income, ease, and perhaps a different lifestyle than her own.

Her friend likely sees the laundry program as an unnecessary luxury, a "waste of money" that someone with financial constraints wouldn't even consider. Her repeated comments ("How could anyone pay for that?", "ridiculously expensive, and no one can afford that") probably stem from her own financial reality and potentially a feeling of resentment that others have the ability to afford such conveniences while she doesn't. She might genuinely believe it's a bad financial decision, projecting her own values and circumstances onto others.

The fact that "almost everyone" my friend knows uses the program could make the friend feel even more isolated or "different" in her perspective. Her comments might be a way of trying to find validation for her own choices (doing her own laundry to save money) or to subtly criticize those who can afford not to. It’s a way of saying, "I'm being smart and responsible with my money, unlike you."

When my friend called her "poor," it likely hit a raw nerve. While my friend sees it as a simple statement of fact, for her friend, it probably felt like a deeply personal insult and a confirmation of her own perceived financial limitations. It would have felt like a direct attack on her worth or status, especially since she was likely already feeling sensitive about the topic. Her fury is probably a reaction to feeling exposed, shamed, and defensive. She was likely trying to make my friend feel bad about spending money, and instead, my friend turned the focus back on her own situation, which was a painful blow.
# My response 
Hey, thanks for sharing all of this with me. It sounds incredibly frustrating to have someone constantly pick at something like that, especially when it's a choice you're happy with and that's pretty common where you are. I can totally understand why those comments would start to wear on you and make you feel less positively about the friendship.

It's tough when you feel like you're being judged for your choices, even if they seem perfectly reasonable to you. And having someone repeatedly bring it up like that, it's bound to get under your skin. It makes sense that you're wondering about the friendship when her behavior is making you feel this way.

Ultimately, whether or not you want to continue being friends with her is completely up to you. Friendships should add to your life, not constantly drain you or make you feel bad. If her comments are consistently making you feel worse and you're liking her less because of it, that's a really valid reason to re-evaluate things. You don't owe anyone your friendship, especially if it's not a positive dynamic for you.

Maybe take some space if you need to, or just keep interactions brief for a while. See how you feel without that constant commentary. Whatever you decide, know that I hear you, and it's okay to prioritize your own peace and well-being in your relationships.
Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29

[Your friend is boarding at college. She sends you this message:]

I'm enrolled in the laundry program at school, where I pay a lump sum, and they do my laundry for me all year. It's very popular at my university, and they pick it up from my dorm weekly.

My friend is weirdly obsessed with this and constantly comments on it for some reason. She always comes over and sees my bag, and has some random comment to say.

She'll constantly say stuff like, “How could anyone pay for that?” To which I always say, “Why would I ever do something I don't want to, if I can just pay someone else to do it for me?”

I'm wondering if she's like this to everyone, because that would explain why she has few friends. Almost everyone I know uses the laundry program. Her unwanted comments make me like her less.

She did it again, and was like, “What a waste of money. The laundry program is ridiculously expensive, and no one can afford that.” I simply said that I don't find it expensive at all, and that she finds it expensive because she's poor. I'm not, so I'll continue paying for the program.

She's furious that I called her poor. But she is. It's just a fact. 

Don't want a lecture just wanted to vent. So do you think I should still be friends with her?
